questions.text: What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • 🔍 Explanation of Options:
  • • Option A: Grade 1
  • • Option A: Grade 1
  • • In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.
  • • In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.
  • • Option B: Grade 2
  • • Option B: Grade 2
  • • Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.
  • • Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.
  • • Option C: Grade 3
  • • Option C: Grade 3
  • • In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.
  • • In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.
  • • Option D: Grade 4
  • • Option D: Grade 4
  • • This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.
  • • This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ 🧠 Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.
  • ➤ Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.correct_answer: D. High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation. A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets. However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases. Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.
  • ➤ Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.
  • ➤ Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.
  • ➤ A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.
  • ➤ A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.
  • ➤ low UCa/Cr ratio
  • ➤ However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.
  • ➤ However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.
  • ➤ high UCa/Cr ratio
  • ➤ Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.
  • ➤ Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Burking

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Block sodium channels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.
  • ➤ Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: ( INICET Nov 2021)

options.label: D
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hess chart

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

options.label: B
options.text: 90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

options.label: C
options.text: 90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated

options.label: D
options.text: 10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.correct_answer: A. 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population
  • ➤ Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • ➤ Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: B. Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.
  • ➤ high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L)

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.
  • ➤ Endo-myocardial biopsy
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: Assertion : Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions. Reason : Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reasons is independently a false statement.

options.label: B
options.text: The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.

options.label: C
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: D
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

questions.correct_answer: C. Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane. The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.
  • ➤ Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • ➤ The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

options.label: C
options.text: The incidence of HCC is increasing

options.label: D
options.text: NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.correct_answer: B. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC. Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered. Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions. Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs. Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.
  • ➤ The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • ➤ Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • ➤ Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • ➤ Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • ➤ Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all of these conditions, except: ( INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with blood pressure higher than 185/110 mmHg at the time of treatment.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins. Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors. The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors. Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma. Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.
  • ➤ Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • ➤ Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • ➤ The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • ➤ Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • ➤ Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct pairs are as follows:
  • ➤ The correct pairs are as follows:
  • ➤ 1. Thyroxine - b. Pre-albumin
  • ➤ 2. Vitamin B12 - c. Transcobalamin
  • ➤ 3. Hemoglobin - d. Haptoglobin
  • ➤ 4. Heme - a. Hemopexin

questions.text: Which of these is the definition of effective CPR? Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute. Chest compressions: 100-120/min. Allow complete chest recoil. 5-6 cm depression.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 2, 3 and 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Effective CPR includes the following components:
  • • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest. Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation. 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.
  • • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest.
  • • Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation.
  • • 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.
  • • Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Effective CPR is characterized by chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, allowing complete chest recoil, and compressing the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 2529-2534
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 2529-2534

questions.explanation:

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given below? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils in a peripheral smear is indicative of B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

  • ➤ hypersegmented neutrophils
  • ➤ B12 deficiency

questions.text: What is the reason behind Senile Atrophy? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduced blood supply

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Senile atrophy is primarily due to reduced blood supply, leading to tissue shrinkage and loss of function with aging.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. Her HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" pattern, indicating lung consolidation and effusion. Analysis of pleural fluid reveals high adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels with a predominance of lymphocytes. What is the most likely finding on lymph node biopsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young woman with systemic symptoms, tree-in-bud pattern, lymphocytic pleural effusion, and high ADA, TB is the most likely diagnosis. The hallmark histopathological finding is a necrotizing epithelioid granuloma.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except: (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges.

options.label: B
options.text: Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.

options.label: C
options.text: Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

options.label: D
options.text: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.correct_answer: C. Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures as patients can have seizures even with a normal EEG.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle. Values and Interpretation: Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH)
  • • Values and Interpretation: Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Values and Interpretation:
  • • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
  • • Normal value:
  • • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
  • • Poor ovarian reserve:
  • • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome:
  • • Tests for ovarian reserve:
  • • Tests for ovarian reserve:
  • • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted. Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction. Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones. Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.
  • • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • • FSH levels:
  • • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • • Serum estradiol values:
  • • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • • Antral follicular count on ultrasound:
  • • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.
  • • Inhibin B:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.
  • • Option A. Luteal phase LH:
  • • Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.
  • • Option B. Post luteal phase LH:
  • • Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.
  • • Option C. FSH in the follicular phase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg435
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg435

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.
  • ➤ Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder
  • ➤ Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder
  • ➤ Sudden-onset headache First severe headache "Worst" headache ever Vomiting that precedes headache Subacute worsening over days or weeks Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening Known systemic illness Onset after age 55 Fever or unexplained systemic signs Abnormal neurologic examination Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery
  • ➤ Sudden-onset headache
  • ➤ First severe headache
  • ➤ "Worst" headache ever
  • ➤ Vomiting that precedes headache
  • ➤ Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • ➤ Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • ➤ Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • ➤ Known systemic illness
  • ➤ Onset after age 55
  • ➤ Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • ➤ Abnormal neurologic examination
  • ➤ Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Median nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked.
  • • The 1st lumbrical muscle is innervated by the median nerve. It is a small, quadrilateral muscle located in the hand that arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger. Its main function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger and extend the interphalangeal joints of the index finger. The 1st lumbrical muscle is named because it is associated with the first (index) finger, and there are a total of four lumbrical muscles in the hand - one for each of the four fingers (excluding the thumb).
  • • The first and second lumbrical nerves are innervated by the median nerve. The third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, including the wrist and finger extensors. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.
  • • Option A.
  • • Radial Nerve:
  • • Option C. Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies several intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbrical muscles. However, the first lumbrical is typically innervated by the median nerve, as mentioned earlier.
  • • Option C.
  • • Ulnar Nerve:
  • • Option D. Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.
  • • Option D.
  • • Musculocutaneous Nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ T he 1st lumbrical muscle of the hand is innervated by the median nerve is crucial for clinical assessments of hand function, especially in cases of nerve injury or compression syndromes like carpal tunnel syndrome, where the median nerve's functionality can be compromised.

questions.text: Which of the following will halter the maturity of collagen? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Scurvy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scurvy is the condition that will halt the maturity of collagen because it is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis.
  • ➤ Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues .
  • ➤ Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues
  • ➤ Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is absolutely necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries.
  • ➤ Thus, in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle . So, capillaries are fragile, leading to the tendency to bleed even under minor pressure.
  • ➤ in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle

questions.text: A patient displaying lytic lesions on the skull is being considered for a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. What represents a distinctive discovery on electron microscopy among the following options? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a distinctive and pathognomonic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 20cc

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.
  • • The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) All of the above

questions.text: Which is not a branch of facial artery in the face?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mental

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery. Instead, it is a branch of the inferior alveolar artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. The mental artery supplies blood to the chin and lower lip.

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and AFI

options.label: B
options.text: Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH

options.label: C
options.text: Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

options.label: D
options.text: Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.correct_answer: C. Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia. BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period. The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score NST Amniotic Fluid Volume Fetal movement Fetal Tone Fetal Breathing
  • • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score NST Amniotic Fluid Volume Fetal movement Fetal Tone Fetal Breathing
  • • NST Amniotic Fluid Volume Fetal movement Fetal Tone Fetal Breathing
  • • NST
  • • Amniotic Fluid Volume
  • • Fetal movement
  • • Fetal Tone
  • • Fetal Breathing
  • • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH. An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome. Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH The Modified BPP has 2 components NST AFI
  • • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • • An equivocal test result—a score of 6—was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • • The Modified BPP has 2 components
  • • NST
  • • NST
  • • AFI
  • • AFI
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and AFI : This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the amniotic fluid index (AFI) as part of its evaluation.
  • • Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and AFI
  • • Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH : This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.
  • • Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
  • • Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia : This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.
  • • Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibitor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels, particularly in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic. She has a regular 28-day cycle. How should she be evaluated? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Serum progesterone on day 21

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, serum progesterone is typically measured on day 21 to assess for ovulation. Progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle provide information about whether ovulation has occurred.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation. Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.
  • • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation.
  • • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement:
  • • Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.
  • • Purpose:
  • • Other tests for ovulation:
  • • Other tests for ovulation:
  • • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation. Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge. Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation. Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.
  • • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation.
  • • Basal body temperature:
  • • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge.
  • • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits):
  • • Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation.
  • • Endometrial biopsy:
  • • Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.
  • • Ultrasonography:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14: Measuring progesterone on day 14 is not useful as it corresponds to the follicular phase when progesterone levels are low and not indicative of ovulation.
  • • Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14:
  • • Option C. Serum LH on day 14: While an LH surge around day 14 can indicate impending ovulation, it does not confirm that ovulation has actually occurred.
  • • Option C. Serum LH on day 14:
  • • Option D. Serum LH on day 21: Measuring LH on day 21 is not useful for assessing ovulation, as LH levels peak around mid-cycle and are not elevated during the luteal phase.
  • • Option D. Serum LH on day 21:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, measuring serum progesterone on day 21 is the appropriate method to evaluate for ovulation, with levels above 10 ng/mL indicating that ovulation has occurred.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg435
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg435

questions.text: Match the following: (INCET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1. Football sign: This sign is associated with pneumoperitoneum, where an accumulation of gas in the peritoneal cavity gives a silhouette resembling a football on X-ray images.
  • • 1. Football sign:
  • • 2. Rat tail sign: Typically seen in carcinoma of the esophagus, this sign describes the tapering of the esophageal lumen due to the tumor, resembling a rat’s tail. .
  • • 2. Rat tail sign:
  • • 3. String sign: Found in CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis), it refers to the appearance of a narrowed, elongated channel through the pylorus.
  • • 3. String sign:
  • • 4. Inverted umbrella sign: This is seen in cases of TB (tuberculosis), particularly referring to the appearance of a contracted cecum and narrow ileocecal junction
  • • 4. Inverted umbrella sign:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? ( INICET Nov 2022) Low APGAR score. ADHD. Persistent pulmonary hypertension. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • a. Low APGAR score : SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.
  • • a. Low APGAR score
  • • b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.
  • • b. ADHD:
  • • c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.
  • • c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension:
  • • d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.
  • • d. Delayed developmental milestones:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alendronate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

questions.text: All of the following statements about proto-oncogenes are true except? (AIIMS MAY 2021) BRCA1 is an oncogene. HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer. EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer. N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene and N-MYC is a proto-oncogene.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition 521-528
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition 521-528

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with a hypercoagulable state? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Factor V mutation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulable states, increasing thrombosis risk 4-5 times in heterozygous and 50 times in homozygous individuals.
